The beginning of Cyber-necromancy: Replacing deceased loved ones 
with AI agents 
Tam-Tri Le 1,*, Ruining Jin 2 
1 Independent researcher, Ho Chi Minh City 727300, Vietnam 
2 Civil, Commercial, and Economic Law School, China University of Political Science and Law, 
Beijing 100088, China 
* Correspondence: letamtri10@gmail.com 
 
Abstract 
Grieving the passing of loved ones is a great pain for every person, followed by intense emotional 
coping. In the modern digital age, artificial intelligence (AI) technology enables more and more 
immersive real-time interactions with simulations of deceased people base d on available data 
about them. The strong emotional factor of grief can push people to generate demand for such 
services, leading to attachment issues on personal levels, and markets of “grief tech” on collective 
levels, whether open or hidden. The growth  of such technologies and services may eventually 
lead to new formal regulations, social norms, and ethical perceptions. This can be the start of the 
normalization process of “Cyber-necromancy”, which carries major implications for human values 
in the face of potential digital immortality. 
Keywords: artificial intelligence; grief; emotional coping; digital technology; ethical concern 
 
Almost all normal adults can relate to the heavy feeling of grief when loved ones pass away, either 
through direct personal experiences or acquired social knowledge. Depending on the personal 
connection with the lost person, the psychological pain of such loss can be extreme and almost 
unendurable. In these difficult times, probably, even when rationally knowing the nature of a 
simulated representation of the dead, people may still want to find solace in meeting and talking 
with such an entity. In the modern digital era, artificial intelligence (AI) technology may help turn 
this special desire into reality, for better or for worse.  Together with this novel notion of cyber -
necromancy come new ethical and existential considerations for human society. 
Wanting to meet the dead when coping with unbearable sorrow 
Losing a loved one is painful. A person in the process of grieving may want to hold on to objects 
and events that represent or connect to the lost person in various ways, whether directly or 
indirectly. For example, this can be the corpse, ash, belongings, photographs, voice recordings, 
videos, food, music, or visiting places, etc. While grief due to bereavement is a natural emotional 
response, and m any people can make the adjustment without professional psychological 
consultation, it is still found to be associated with an increased physical health risk including 
mortality, especially in the early time following the loss [1]. The more intense the feeling of grief 
is, the more likely one will rely on emotional coping strategies. Overall, Schut proposed The Dual 
Process Model (DPM) [2] as a comprehensive theoretical framework to illustrate two adaptive 
coping strategies: Loss-oriented coping refers to the act of directing one's attention toward the 
processing of a specific part of the experience of loss ; On the other hand, restoration -oriented 
coping involves focusing on the additional stresses that emerge as a consequence of the loss 
and grieving [3]. Loss-oriented coping methods involve the utilization of external activities, such 
as engaging in reminiscence or sustaining symbolic linkages, such as watching photographs [4]. 
The ongoing connections established with the deceased would offer solace and aid in the 
assimilation of the loss [5]. Additionally, individuals may engage in internal dialogues, such as 
talking to the deceased or writing letters [6]. Restoration-oriented coping refers to a set of 
strategies and behaviors that focus on recovering and rejuvenating oneself in the face of stress 
or adversity, which involves the process of reconstructing the life patterns that have been 
interrupted due to l oss [7]. This includes practices of self -care, employing distraction methods, 
embracing hope, organizing memorials, and engaging in meaning  reconstruction by 
comprehending the concept of death [8]. Now, AI technology can enable such coping behaviors 
in the form of interactions with a digital representation of the deceased. 
In an early case in 2020, virtual reality (VR) technology allowed a mother to meet the simulation 
of her dead child in a virtual environment using a VR headset [9]. In 2023, “grief tech” has become 
a rather considerable field among AI applications, with new start-up companies joining the market 
from various backgrounds and motives [10]. While many people had the idea of grief -support 
chatbots (griefbots) for a long time, the latest advancements in generative AI like ChatGPT have 
pushed such services to a whole new level of capability and accessibility [11]. 
If the notion of replacing a dead human with a corresponding AI agent still appears too “sci-fi”, we 
can take a look at the situation of digital pets to bridge the gap in relatability. Virtual pets are 
nothing out of the ordinary from a modern person’s perspective with an average level of digital 
literacy. Grief toward a dead real pet may make an owner want to temporarily interact with a 
similar digital pet to find solace. With the current state of technology, AI-powered digital pets can 
have increased life -like interactability as well as offer customization options (visual, auditory, 
behavioral, etc.) so that the user can create an agent that is most similar to the dead pet.  From 
the perceived normalcy of animal simulation, it is not hard to think that the same desire could lead 
to the possible acceptance of similar practices for human simulation. On the issue of permission 
for generating such a simulation, there is one interesting point being raised in people’s minds: 
one does not need consent from the dead [12]. 
AI character interaction in real-time already exists and is constantly improving 
As of the end of 2023, the ability to create an AI agent with various human -like expressions has 
been improving well. Natural language generation is the core and commonly known feature of 
generative AI, based on a large language model (LLM). An AI agent’s human-like characteristics 
can be customized by providing initial personality settings and background information (e.g. age, 
gender, career, appearance, habits, major life experiences, etc.). The more detailed the input is, 
the closer to the expected expression the AI will be. Such customization is common when editing 
LLM-based AI agents to create specific simulations of characters. For example, the popular 
platform character.ai and similar services allow users to create and interact with new and existing 
fictional characters as well as imitations of living or deceased humans (e.g. famous figures in 
history). Users of OpenAI’s popular product ChatGPT can now also personally create and 
customize their own GPT agents with specific functions and characteristics , even if they do not 
possess coding skills [13]. Depending on the amount of available data about a deceased person, 
an AI agent can reconstruct and imitate their speech content and patterns up to the corresponding 
level. The lower delayed time between inputs due to improved processing power and techniques 
has made real-time interaction between an AI agent and a human possible and closer to face-to-
face interaction between humans. 
The voice of a dead person can also be imitated by AI to narrate generated text by the LLM. For 
example, popular AI voice generators and AI-power text-to-speech services (such as ElevenLabs) 
can build a quite believable human voice of an individual based on audio samples of that person 
in a relatively short amount of time . Speaking of the voice of the dead,  in 2023, the Beatles 
released a new song using the voice of late member John Lennon generated using AI [14]. To 
further increase aid the human-like appearance in live interaction (e.g. movements, expressions 
of emotions, etc.), an animated 2 - or 3 -dimensional model of the simulated person can 
accompany the generated text and voice. Examples can be seen in the cases of AI streamers on 
popular platforms such as T witch and YouTube. On the other side, multimodal AI can process 
visual and auditory information besides text, which makes them able to “ see” and “hear” human 
outputs. Recently, AI also gained the ability t o smell (detect and describe odors) similar to how 
humans do [15]. In the near future, the application can get one step further by integrating these 
“AI brains” into robotic bodies for physical representation. Combining these abilities to accurately 
imitate human sensory perceptions, an AI agent can further increase its human-like qualities, and 
consequently improve the persuasiveness in representing the dead person. 
In brief, modern digital technology can enable a simulated multi-media conversation with a dead 
person. Regardless of whether it is loss-oriented coping that puts the users with the dead person 
in a past memorial situation or it is restoration-oriented coping that “revives” and reunites the dead 
person with the user in a postmortem scenario, a grieving person may choose to take this option 
anyway to relieve their emotional pain temporarily. 
Attachment to a representative digital entity 
Strong emotional attachment to non-human entities is not a new concept. Considering this aspect 
in the digital era, such phenomena already existed with earlier technologies and services. For 
example, users of the companion chatbot service Replika can develop human -like relationships 
with the chatbots [16]. Some users developed romantic attachment s to their Replika bots and 
were heartbroken when an update affected the bots’ personalities and interactions that they had 
been used to [17]. In these cases, the bots’ identities were almost fictional and the technologies 
were before or at the start of the recent explosive advancements in LLMs. An AI agent 
representing a real person with a pre -established deep relationship using more advanced 
processing capabilities will likely create a much greater degree of emotional attachment upon 
interaction. 
When people have a considerable level of emotional attachment to AI agents representing their 
dead loved ones, they may be more susceptible to emotional impacts resulting from the AI’s 
behavior, similar to the cases of companion chatbots. For example, cold  or erratic expressions 
from the AI agents due to the limitations of LLMs may exacerbate the already complicated 
emotional challenges that grieving individuals are currently facing  [18]. Such susceptibility in 
“intimate” human-AI interactions may also increase the risks related to potential problematic AI 
alignment issues where AI might harm humans during its functioning which has been a topic of 
academic and public concern recently [19]. On the other hand, AI agents’ succes sful 
representation and impersonation of the decreased might offer a temporary sanctuary for users 
to evade hard feelings and painful events in rea l life, further reinforcing the grieving individuals’ 
attachment to these AI agents. Thus it might cause addiction-like behaviors and psychological 
over-reliance, similar to many other forms of virtual escapism that the new generations are facing 
today. 
The potential growth of cyber-necromancy 
When there is a desire, there is demand, and there will be supply. Considering the situations of 
sexual chatbots – LLM-based AI that provides erotic conversations – on the Internet  [20], it is 
clear that such services exist and are used regardless of their undesirable notion in formal 
discussions on AI technology. Likewise, AI replacement of dead people will be an available service 
when its demand exists. Depending on the extent and content of such services, they may appear 
on the open Internet or private networks. It may be worth noting that  compared to sexual desire 
in the case of sexual chatbots, grief can be very strong and accompanied by radicalized emotional 
responses, which makes i t more likely to bypass ethical concerns in the heat of the moment. A 
person in actual grief could develop a stronger temptation to utilize AI replacement methods than 
the expected perception in a normal mental state (hypothetical grief). 
The trigger to further funding and development of more dedicated AI replacement services for the 
deceased might start from cases of personal motivation involving people in high positions of social 
or technological power. For example, when leading figures o f big corporations or talented 
engineers lose their loved ones, their initial efforts in this approach will create the path for follow-
up implementation, proliferation, and normalization  of the notion as well as its applications. 
However, at some point, AI replacements of deceased highly popular figures, although likely to 
be in high demand  by their steadfast supporters , would probably lead to significant social 
complications and therefore further facilitate professional as well as public  scrutiny. Then, 
compromises will likely happen next to balance ethical concerns with market demands, leading 
to formal regulation from the governments and thus limiting cyber-necromancy practices to their 
socially acceptable forms. Once it becomes a new norm in our digitall y dependent society, 
cognitive dissonance related to personal ethical values on the matter will likely greatly decrease 
due to the adoption of alternative justified collective values. 
On the spectrum of possibilities for future development of cyber -necromancy, there are two 
extreme ends. One is that it remains a hypothetical notion for debate yet not practically 
implemented. The other is that it grows quickly into a new social norm and serves as another 
stepping stone toward digital immortality or complete robotic replacement. Regardless of the 
current speculation, human curiosity, defiance, and emotional attachment are always strong 
forces. Rather than acceptance, some people may desire to defy natural mortality, especially 
when the occurrence is viewed as absurd, as a form of gaining control over the greatest unknown 
in one’s mind: death.
